Award.AwardTitle: Effects of Maternal and Paternal Responsiveness on Infant Attention and Language Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Babies vary significantly in their rate of language acquisition during the first few years of life. Disparities in language development and vocabulary growth in particular can have long term impacts for children's later academic success. How parents interact with and respond to their babies is one factor that has an important impact on babies' language development. However, it is unclear how social interactions and parent responses influence developmental change in infants. The current research will explore how parent responses to babies' vocalizations affect the babies' visual attention in the moment as a potential pathway to longer-term language development. Understanding the relations among responsiveness, visual attention, and subsequent language development can reveal how everyday social interactions support language learning.

Mothers' and fathers' social interactions with their 6- to 12-month-old infants will be observed. Observation periods will be coded for infant vocalization, parental responsiveness, and infant visual attention following parental responses. The data will be analyzed for relations between infant vocalizations and parent responses, between parent responses and infant attention, and between observations and subsequent language development as indexed by parental report language questionnaires administered when infants are 15 and 24 months of age. Broad hypotheses include: parent responses will affect infant attention and this will influence language learning; parents will be more responsive to behaviors that are more speech-like and communicative; different types of parent responses will affect infant behavior differently --some responses will more positively impact language development. An important outcome of the research project will be linking parents' responsiveness and infants' visual attention and variation in vocabulary growth to help understand individual differences in language development. The findings will inform theories of development by relating the dynamics of moment-to-moment behaviors to learning and development. Furthermore, the research findings have the potential to inform interventions or parenting advice to promote language development in all children, particularly those who are at risk for delays.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the research project is to explore the relationship between parent responses to infant vocalizations and how these affect infant attention and language development. Three related projects observed mothers and fathers in social interactions with their infants between 6 and 12 months of age. The research team documented specific behaviors during these interactions to see how early infant vocal development is related to parent behavior in social interactions. Also, we examined how infant language development at (18 and 24 months) was affected by parent responses. 

We found that parents respond to more speech like sounds differently than they respond to sounds that are less advanced. This was in line with previous findings from our lab, providing further support for the interaction and two-way effects of infant vocalizations on parents' responses. Parents vary in how responsive they are to infant vocal behavior, and how they respond. Certain types of responses that are related to what infants focus on (parents' 'talk about' what infants are looking at and what they are doing) are associated with language development. Also, we found that these responses are associated with infants holding their attention on the toys that they are playing with when parents respond. Therefore, we propose that parents' responses relate to infant attention, which supports language learning.

An important research outcome of the research project is understanding how social responsiveness affects language and communication. By studying this mechanism of development, we can better understand individual differences in language outcomes. We can also provide information from our research to clinical researchers which could help develop interventions for children with developemntal delays.

The research project has an impact beyond the findings in the lab. The research team over the period of the grant involved 23 undergraduates, some of whom were from underrepresented groups in the sciences. These students gained important research, communication, and teamwork skills as part of their training for further career pursuits. The PI also provided lab tours to high school students interested in science careers. Lastly, the PI is involved in groups to share research findings with new parents and people who offer interventions for children who are delayed in language development. Therefore, the research findings will be communicated to groups who have a common interest and goals for improving children's language development.
